docs.text: Python Python is a popular programming language this day. Python is versatile and is independent to operating system. This site contains some quick notes about Python that I compiled from time to time for my easy reference. Hopefully these notes can also be useful for any one who is interested in learning Python. For those who would like to learn more about Python, you can check out a list of resources below: Python from the Very Beginning , J. Whitington, Leaving the Rat Race with Python: An Insider's Guide to Freelance Developing , L. Rieger, C. Mayer, Actionable Python 3.8 , Nat Dunn, Webucator, Learning IoT with Python and Raspberry Pi , E.I. Horvath E.A. Horvath, Learn Programming in Python with Cody Jackson , Cody Jackson, Python 3 Object-Oriented Programming - Third Edition , Dusty Phillips, For online platform, there are a lot of materials available online, for example: The Python Standard Library , Fredrik Lundh Python Cookbook , ActiveState Others
docs.title: Home

docs.text: Some notes on Markdown Commands mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project. mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server. mkdocs build - Build the documentation site. mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit. Project layout mkdocs.yml # The configuration file. docs/ index.md # The documentation homepage. ... # Other markdown pages, images and other files. Adding abbreviations The HTML specification is maintained by the W3C . Adding glossary using snippets to import the glossary from another file. The HTML specification is maintained by the W3C . docs.title: Math with MathJax

docs.text: Virtualenv Virtualen is a virtual Python environment builder. It helps a user to create multiple Python environments side-by-side. Thereby, it can avoid compatibility issues between the different versions of the libraries. to install virtualenv pip install virtualenv a new virtual environment can be created as follows virtualenv venv To activate the environment: Linux/Mac: venv/bin/activate Windows: venv\Scripts\activate
docs.title: Virtualenv

docs.text: Virtualen is a virtual Python environment builder. It helps a user to create multiple Python environments side-by-side. Thereby, it can avoid compatibility issues between the different versions of the libraries. to install virtualenv pip install virtualenv a new virtual environment can be created as follows virtualenv venv To activate the environment: Linux/Mac: venv/bin/activate Windows: venv\Scripts\activate
docs.title: Virtualenv

docs.text: Visual Studio Code Visual Studio Code (VS Code) is currently my all time favorite code editor. It is lightweight and has built-in support for JavaScript, TypeScript and Node.js. It also support additional programming language like Python. You can learn more about VS Code here . If you would like to use VS Code for your Python development, first download and install the VS Code from this link . After setting up VS Code, go to the Extension , then download and install the Python extension for VS Code You can found the Extension icon on the left panel of VS Code. Some Notes Nowadays, many computers already have Python installed. To check the version of Python installed in your computer, type the following command in your PowerShell or CMD : C:\Users\Your Name> python --version Besides code editor like VS Code or Notepad++, we can also use an IDE , such as Thonny , Pycharm , Netbeans or Eclipse to write our Python code. These IDEs are useful when dealing with large collections of Python files.
docs.title: Visual Studio Code
